The Special Publication 800-series reports on ITL’s research, guidelines, and 96  outreach efforts in information system security, and its collaborative activities with industry, 97  government, and academic organizations. 98  Abstract 99  The HIPAA Security Rule focuses on safeguarding electronic protected health information 100  (ePHI) held or maintained by regulated entities. The ePHI that a regulated entity creates, 101  receives, maintains, or transmits must be protected against reasonably anticipated threats, 102  hazards, and impermissible uses and/or disclosures. Rule], as amended by 196  the Modifications to the HIPAA Privacy, Security, Enforcement, and Breach Notification Rules 197  Under the Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act [HITECH] and 198  the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act; Other Modifications to the HIPAA Rules 199  [Omnibus Rule]1 and assist regulated entities2 in their implementation of the Security Rule. It 200  includes a brief overview of the HIPAA Security Rule, provides guidance for regulated entities 201  on assessing and managing risks to electronic protected health information (ePHI), identifies 202  typical activities that a regulated entity might consider implementing as part of an information 203  security program, and lists additional resources that regulated entities may find useful in 204  implementing the Security Rule. 205  The HIPAA Security Rule specifically focuses on protecting the confidentiality, integrity, and 206  availability of ePHI, as defined in the Security Rule. All HIPAA regulated entities must comply 207  with the requirements of the Security Rule. The ePHI that a regulated entity creates, receives, 208  maintains, or transmits must be protected against reasonably anticipated threats, hazards, and 209  impermissible uses and/or disclosures. In general, the requirements, standards, and 210  implementation specifications of the Security Rule apply to the following regulated entities:  211  • Covered Healthcare Providers – Any provider of medical or other health services or 212  supplies who transmits any health information in electronic form in connection with a 213  transaction for which the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) has 214  adopted a standard. 215  • Health Plans – Any individual or group plan that provides or pays the cost of medical 216  care (e.g., a health insurance issuer and the Medicare and Medicaid programs). 217  • Healthcare Clearinghouses – A public or private entity that processes another entity’s 218  healthcare transactions from a standard format to a non-standard format or vice versa. 219  • Business Associate – A person or entity3 that performs certain functions or activities that 220  involve the use or disclosure of protected health information on behalf of or provides 221  services to a covered entity. A business associate is liable for their own HIPAA 222  violations.  223  The Security Rule is separated into six main sections that each include several standards that a 224  regulated entity must address. Many of the standards contain implementation specifications. An 225  implementation specification is a more detailed description of the method or approach that 226  regulated entities can use to meet a particular standard. Implementation specifications are either 227  required or addressable. Regulated entities must comply with required implementation 228  specifications. Rule] 362  specifically focuses on safeguarding electronic protected health information (ePHI). All HIPAA-363  covered entities and business associates must comply with the requirements of the Security Rule. 364  Throughout this publication, covered entities and business associates will be referred to as 365  “regulated entities.” Whenever the term regulated entity or regulated entities appears, it is to 366  be understood as applying to both covered entities and business associates as defined in the 367  Security Rule.  368  1.1 Purpose and Scope 369  NIST Special Publication (SP) 800-66 aims to help educate readers about the security standards 370  included in the HIPAA Security Rule and assist regulated entities in their implementation of the 371  Security Rule. It includes a brief overview of the HIPAA Security Rule, provides guidance for 372  regulated entities in assessing and managing risk to ePHI, identifies typical activities that a 373  regulated entity should consider when implementing an information security program, and lists 374  additional resources that regulated entities might find useful in implementing the Security Rule. 375  This publication is intended to be an aid to understanding the HIPAA Security Rule and does not 376  supplement, replace, modify, or supersede the Security Rule itself. Anyone seeking clarifications 377  of the HIPAA Security Rule should contact the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services 378  (HHS) Office for Civil Rights (OCR). For general HIPAA Security Rule information, visit the 379  HHS Security Rule website.4  380  The NIST publications available as of the publication date of SP 800-66, Rev. 2, were used in 381  preparing this document. NIST frequently publishes new standards and guidelines or updates 382  existing publications that may also serve as useful references. To remain current with the latest 383  available list of NIST security publications, the reader should periodically visit the NIST 384  Computer Security Resource Center (CSRC5). 385  1.2 Applicability 386  The guidance provided in this publication is applicable to all covered entities and their business 387  associates of all sizes throughout the world that store, process, or transmit ePHI. While the 388  Security Rule requires regulated entities to protect ePHI, covered entities are required by the 389  Privacy Rule6 to protect all forms of protected health information (PHI). The HIPAA Privacy 390  Rule at 164.530(c)(1) states, “A covered entity must have in place appropriate administrative, 391  technical, and physical safeguards to protect the privacy of protected health information.” 392  Essentially, this covers all PHI – oral, written, and electronic (to the extent not covered by the 393  Security Rule). This part of the Privacy Rule applies to covered entities, not business associates. 394  However, the business associate agreement (BAA) in place between a covered entity and 395  business associate would cover protections for all PHI. Rule] specifically focuses on protecting the confidentiality, 470  integrity, and availability of ePHI as defined in the Security Rule. The ePHI that a regulated 471  entity creates, receives, maintains, or transmits must be protected against reasonably anticipated 472  threats, hazards, and impermissible uses and/or disclosures. In general, the requirements, 473  standards, and implementation specifications of the Security Rule apply to the following 474  regulated entities:  475  • Covered Healthcare Providers – Any provider of medical or other health services or 476  supplies who transmits any health information in electronic form in connection with a 477  transaction for which HHS has adopted a standard. 478  • Health Plans – Any individual or group plan that provides or pays the cost of medical 479  care (e.g., a health insurance issuer and the Medicare and Medicaid programs). 480  • Healthcare Clearinghouses – A public or private entity that processes another entity’s 481  healthcare transactions from a standard format to a non-standard format or vice versa. 482  • Business Associate – A person or entity9 that performs certain functions or activities that 483  involve the use or disclosure of protected health information on behalf of or provides 484  services to a covered entity. A business associate is liable for its own HIPAA Security 485  Rule violations. 486  2.1 Security Rule Goals and Objectives 487  As required by the “Security standards: General rules” section of the HIPAA Security Rule, each 488  regulated entity must: 489  • Ensure the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of ePHI that it creates, receives, 490  maintains, or transmits; 491  • Protect against any reasonably anticipated threats and hazards to the security or integrity 492  of ePHI;  493  • Protect against reasonably anticipated uses or disclosures of such information that are not 494  permitted by the Privacy Rule; and 495  • Ensure compliance with the Security Rule by its workforce. 496  Regulated entities are reminded of the Security Rule’s flexibility of approach. Cybersecurity 497  practices will vary across organizations, depending on levels of technical understanding, 498  financial and human resources, and risk tolerance. This flexibility allows regulated entities to 499  customize how they implement HIPAA’s Security Rule requirements. In complying with this 500  section of the Security Rule, regulated entities must be aware of the definitions provided for 501  confidentiality, integrity, and availability as given by § 164.304: 502  • Confidentiality is “the property that data or information is not made available or 503  disclosed to unauthorized persons or processes.” 504  9 A member of the covered entity’s workforce is not a business associate. A covered healthcare provider, health plan, or  healthcare clearinghouse can be a business associate of another covered entity. processes are foundational to a regulated entity’s 578  compliance with the Security Rule [Sec. Rule] and the protection of ePHI. Readers are reminded 579  of the Security Rule’s flexibility of approach. HHS OCR does not prescribe any particular risk 580  assessment or risk management methodology. This section provides foundational information 581  about risk assessment and an approach that regulated entities may choose to use in assessing risk 582  to ePHI. Regulated entities are free to use another risk assessment methodology13 that provides a 583  comprehensive assessment of risk to ePHI.  584  This section incorporates the risk assessment concepts and processes described in the NISTIR 585  8286 [IR 8286] series (specifically NISTIR 8286A [IR 8286A], Identifying and Estimating 586  Cybersecurity Risk for Enterprise Risk Management); NIST SP 800-30, Rev. 1, Effective Use of 587  Risk Assessments in Managing Enterprise Risk [SP 800-30]; and NIST SP 800-37, Rev. 2, Risk 588  Management Framework for Information Systems and Organizations: A System Life Cycle 589  Approach for Security and Privacy [SP 800-37]. It is intended to assist regulated entities in 590  identifying risks to ePHI. 591  The purpose of a risk assessment is to identify conditions where ePHI could be used or disclosed 592  without proper authorization, improperly modified, or made unavailable when needed. The 593  results of the risk assessment are used to make risk management decisions on the implementation 594  of security measures required by the Security Rule to bring risk to ePHI into an organizationally 595  established risk tolerance range (i.e., reasonable and appropriate level), or if additional security 596  controls are necessary.  597  Key Terms Defined 598  When talking about risk, it is important that terminology be clearly understood. This subsection 599  defines important terms associated with risk assessment and risk management. 600  • Threat events are circumstances or events that can have a negative impact on ePHI.  601  Threat events can be: 602  o Intentional (e.g., malicious intent)  603  o Unintentional (e.g., misconfigured server, data entry error) 604  • Threat sources refers to the intent and method targeted at causing harm to ePHI. Threat 605  sources can be: 606  o Natural (e.g., floods, earthquakes, storms, tornados), 607  o Human (e.g., intentional, such as identity thieves, hackers, spyware authors; 608  unintentional, such as data entry error, accidental deletions), or 609  o Environmental (e.g., power surges and spikes, hazmat contamination, 610  environmental pollution). 611  • Vulnerabilities are flaws or weaknesses in a system, system security procedures, internal 612  controls, or implementation that could be exploited or triggered by a threat event.  613  13 Regulated entities may benefit from the NISTIR 8286 series of publications for more comprehensive risk assessment  methodologies, including how to integrate ePHI risk assessment with Enterprise Risk Management (ERM). Risk Appetite and Risk Tolerance  NISTIR 8286A presents two concepts – risk appetite and risk tolerance – that may be helpful  to regulated entities in managing risk to ePHI. Risk appetite regarding cybersecurity risks is  declared at the enterprise (i.e., highest) level of the organization and provides a guidepost to  the types and amount of risk, on a broad level, that senior leaders are willing to accept in  pursuit of mission objectives. Risk tolerance represents the specific level of performance  risk deemed acceptable within the risk appetite set by senior leadership. Regulated entities  may choose to express risk tolerance qualitatively (e.g., Very Low, Low, Moderate, High,  or Very High) in alignment with the guidance presented in Section 3.  Risk appetite and risk tolerance are related but distinct. Where risk appetite statements define  the overarching risk guidance, risk tolerance statements define the specific application of that  direction. This means that risk tolerance statements are always more specific than the  corresponding risk appetite statements. Together, risk appetite and risk tolerance statements  represent risk limits that can assist regulated entities in managing risk to ePHI. In the [NIST CSF], for example, six informative 1437  references were included (as shown in Figure 1) although many other informative references 1438  could have been useful to stakeholders. While the concept of informative references was well 1439  received, the static nature of the Cybersecurity Framework and other NIST documents that 1440  include informative references meant that some of its informative references became outdated as 1441  the documents they referenced were updated. 1442  1443  1444  Within the context of the National Online Informative References [NIST OLIR] Program, an 1445  informative reference indicates the relationship(s) between the elements of two documents. The 1446  source document, called the Focal Document, is used as the basis for the document comparison. 1447  The second document is called the Reference Document. Note that a Focal Document or a 1448  Reference Document is not necessarily in a traditional document format (e.g., a formal 1449  publication in PDF format) but could be a product, service, or training. A Focal Document 1450  Element or a Reference Document Element is a discrete section, sentence, phrase, or other 1451  identifiable piece of content of a document. 1452  The OLIR Program is a NIST effort to facilitate subject matter experts (SMEs) in defining 1453  standardized relationships between elements of their cybersecurity, privacy, and workforce 1454  documents (Reference Documents) and elements of other cybersecurity, privacy, and workforce 1455  documents (Focal Documents), like the Cybersecurity Framework Version 1.1 and NIST [SP 1456  800-53], Rev. 5. By removing the informative references from within the NIST documents, the 1457  OLIR program scales to accommodate a greater number of informative references while 1458  providing a more agile model for updating the relationships between elements of the Reference 1459  and Focal Documents.  1460  Figure 1 - Informative References Included in Cybersecurity Framework  NIST SP 800-66r2 ipd  IMPLEMENTING THE HIPAA SECURITY RULE:  INITIAL PUBLIC DRAFT  A CYBERSECURITY RESOURCE GUIDE  105  The National OLIR Program provides an online catalog for displaying, sharing, and comparing 1461  informative references. The National OLIR Program offers several benefits, including: 1462  • Provides a single, easy-to-use repository where people can obtain information on many 1463  Reference Documents and analyze their relationships 1464  • Increases the transparency, alignment, and harmonization of definitions and concepts 1465  across Reference Documents 1466  • Standardizes how References are expressed – making them more consistent, clear, usable, 1467  repeatable, and organizable – and provides a way for automation technologies to ingest 1468  and utilize them 1469  • Provides the ability to authenticate the source of each Reference and allows users to 1470  identify whether the Reference was provided by a verified SME 1471  • Employs mathematical rigor (e.g., standard set theory principles, such as subset, superset, 1472  equal, intersect, and discrete logic) to express References rather than merely relying on 1473  prose, which can be ambiguous and subjective 1474  • Allows for the cybersecurity and privacy community to keep information current on 1475  relationship assertions between Reference Documents and Focal Documents 1476  Before the National OLIR Program, a person analyzing documents was often forced to conduct a 1477  manual comparison, typically by copying the contents of both documents into a spreadsheet for 1478  easier searching and sorting. To save time, an analyst might try to leverage existing document 1479  mappings from SMEs. This laborious and error-prone process would be repeated for all of the 1480  elements within the Focal Document and the Reference Document. Multiply this process by 1481  numerous analysts performing the task, and two problems quickly emerge: 1) the different 1482  opinions of analysts result in inconsistent associations, and 2) the analysts duplicate an enormous 1483  amount of effort. Streamlining this process is the main reason the OLIR Derived Relationship 1484  Mappings (DRM) capability was created. 1485  DRMs are the result of using the relationships between Reference Documents and a Focal 1486  Document to make inferences about relationships between the Reference Documents. For 1487  example, the OLIR catalog contains an informative reference that maps elements of the 1488  Cybersecurity Framework to elements in NIST SP 800-53, Rev. 5. Another informative 1489  reference maps elements of the Cybersecurity Framework to elements in two versions of the 1490  HITRUST CSF [HITRUST]. A DRM can be created that depicts the relationships between the 1491  two Reference Documents: NIST SP 800-53, Rev.5 and the HITRUST CSF. These DRMs can be 1492  dynamically generated on the OLIR website. 1493  With much of the relationship data already defined by the SME, a user can simply generate a full 1494  report between two Reference Documents and export it to a comma-separated values format. The 1495  user can sort the reference data by Functions, Categories, Subcategories, Control Families, 1496  Security/Privacy Controls, or Security Control Enhancements (depending on the Focal 1497  Document selected). The user can then better understand the similarities and differences between 1498  the elements and determine which relationships are relevant for their purposes.  1499  In the context of HIPAA compliance, Table 12 in Appendix E lists mappings between elements 1500  of the Security Rule (i.e., standards and implementation specifications); elements of SP 800-53, 1501  Rev. 5 (i.e., security and privacy controls); and elements of the Cybersecurity Framework (i.e., 1502  NIST SP 800-66r2 ipd  IMPLEMENTING THE HIPAA SECURITY RULE:  INITIAL PUBLIC DRAFT  A CYBERSECURITY RESOURCE GUIDE  106  Subcategory outcomes). The ePHI that a regulated 471  entity creates, receives, maintains, or transmits must be protected against reasonably anticipated 472  threats, hazards, and impermissible uses and/or disclosures. A business associate is liable for its own HIPAA Security 485  Rule violations. 486  2.1 Security Rule Goals and Objectives 487  As required by the “Security standards: General rules” section of the HIPAA Security Rule, each 488  regulated entity must: 489  • Ensure the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of ePHI that it creates, receives, 490  maintains, or transmits; 491  • Protect against any reasonably anticipated threats and hazards to the security or integrity 492  of ePHI;  493  • Protect against reasonably anticipated uses or disclosures of such information that are not 494  permitted by the Privacy Rule; and 495  • Ensure compliance with the Security Rule by its workforce. 496  Regulated entities are reminded of the Security Rule’s flexibility of approach. Cybersecurity 497  practices will vary across organizations, depending on levels of technical understanding, 498  financial and human resources, and risk tolerance. This flexibility allows regulated entities to 499  customize how they implement HIPAA’s Security Rule requirements. In complying with this 500  section of the Security Rule, regulated entities must be aware of the definitions provided for 501  confidentiality, integrity, and availability as given by § 164.304: 502  • Confidentiality is “the property that data or information is not made available or 503  disclosed to unauthorized persons or processes.” 504  9 A member of the covered entity’s workforce is not a business associate. The 513  Security Rule is separated into six main sections that each include several standards and 514  implementation specifications that a regulated entity must address.10 The six sections are listed 515  below.  516  1. Security Standards: General Rules – Includes the general requirements that all 517  regulated entities must meet, establishes flexibility of approach, identifies standards and 518  implementation specifications (both required and addressable), outlines decisions that a 519  regulated entity must make regarding addressable implementation specifications, and 520  requires the maintenance of security measures to continue reasonable and appropriate 521  protection of electronic protected health information. 522  2. Administrative Safeguards – Defined in the Security Rule as the “administrative actions 523  and policies, and procedures to manage the selection, development, implementation, and 524  maintenance of security measures to protect electronic protected health information and 525  to manage the conduct of the covered entity's workforce in relation to the protection of 526  that information.” 527  3. processes are foundational to a regulated entity’s 578  compliance with the Security Rule [Sec. Rule] and the protection of ePHI. Readers are reminded 579  of the Security Rule’s flexibility of approach. HHS OCR does not prescribe any particular risk 580  assessment or risk management methodology. This section provides foundational information 581  about risk assessment and an approach that regulated entities may choose to use in assessing risk 582  to ePHI. Regulated entities are free to use another risk assessment methodology13 that provides a 583  comprehensive assessment of risk to ePHI.  584  This section incorporates the risk assessment concepts and processes described in the NISTIR 585  8286 [IR 8286] series (specifically NISTIR 8286A [IR 8286A], Identifying and Estimating 586  Cybersecurity Risk for Enterprise Risk Management); NIST SP 800-30, Rev. 1, Effective Use of 587  Risk Assessments in Managing Enterprise Risk [SP 800-30]; and NIST SP 800-37, Rev. 2, Risk 588  Management Framework for Information Systems and Organizations: A System Life Cycle 589  Approach for Security and Privacy [SP 800-37]. It is intended to assist regulated entities in 590  identifying risks to ePHI. 591  The purpose of a risk assessment is to identify conditions where ePHI could be used or disclosed 592  without proper authorization, improperly modified, or made unavailable when needed. The 593  results of the risk assessment are used to make risk management decisions on the implementation 594  of security measures required by the Security Rule to bring risk to ePHI into an organizationally 595  established risk tolerance range (i.e., reasonable and appropriate level), or if additional security 596  controls are necessary.  597  Key Terms Defined 598  When talking about risk, it is important that terminology be clearly understood. This subsection 599  defines important terms associated with risk assessment and risk management. 600  • Threat events are circumstances or events that can have a negative impact on ePHI.  601  Threat events can be: 602  o Intentional (e.g., malicious intent)  603  o Unintentional (e.g., misconfigured server, data entry error) 604  • Threat sources refers to the intent and method targeted at causing harm to ePHI. Threat 605  sources can be: 606  o Natural (e.g., floods, earthquakes, storms, tornados), 607  o Human (e.g., intentional, such as identity thieves, hackers, spyware authors; 608  unintentional, such as data entry error, accidental deletions), or 609  o Environmental (e.g., power surges and spikes, hazmat contamination, 610  environmental pollution). 611  • Vulnerabilities are flaws or weaknesses in a system, system security procedures, internal 612  controls, or implementation that could be exploited or triggered by a threat event.  613  13 Regulated entities may benefit from the NISTIR 8286 series of publications for more comprehensive risk assessment  methodologies, including how to integrate ePHI risk assessment with Enterprise Risk Management (ERM). Before beginning the risk assessment, the regulated entity 652  should understand where ePHI is created, received, maintained, processed, or transmitted. 653  Identify where ePHI is generated within the organization, where and how it enters the 654  organization (e.g., web portals), where it moves and flows within the organization (e.g., 655  to specific information systems), where it is stored, and where ePHI leaves the 656  organization. Ensure that the risk assessment scope takes teleworkers and any remote work 662  force into consideration, including any external service providers who may have access to 663  ePHI remotely. The scope should include all removable media and portable computing 664  devices (e.g., laptops, mobile devices) as well as the myriad of medical devices (e.g., 665  medical Internet of Things [IoT]) that can store, process, or transmit ePHI. Modern 666  mobile devices may not only contain ePHI but may also pose a greater risk to ePHI due 667  to theft or loss. Risk Appetite and Risk Tolerance  NISTIR 8286A presents two concepts – risk appetite and risk tolerance – that may be helpful  to regulated entities in managing risk to ePHI. Risk appetite regarding cybersecurity risks is  declared at the enterprise (i.e., highest) level of the organization and provides a guidepost to  the types and amount of risk, on a broad level, that senior leaders are willing to accept in  pursuit of mission objectives. Risk tolerance represents the specific level of performance  risk deemed acceptable within the risk appetite set by senior leadership. Regulated entities  may choose to express risk tolerance qualitatively (e.g., Very Low, Low, Moderate, High,  or Very High) in alignment with the guidance presented in Section 3.  Risk appetite and risk tolerance are related but distinct. Where risk appetite statements define  the overarching risk guidance, risk tolerance statements define the specific application of that  direction. This means that risk tolerance statements are always more specific than the  corresponding risk appetite statements. Together, risk appetite and risk tolerance statements  represent risk limits that can assist regulated entities in managing risk to ePHI. Draft, Maintain, and Update  Required Documentation  • Document decisions concerning the management,  operational, and technical controls selected to mitigate  identified risks.  • Written documentation may be incorporated into existing  manuals, policies, and other documents or be created  specifically for the purpose of demonstrating compliance  with the HIPAA Security Rule.  • Consider the importance of documenting the processes and  procedures for demonstrating the adequate implementation  of recognized security practices.  • Use feedback from risk assessments and contingency plan  tests to help determine when to update documentation.  • Are all required policies and procedures documented?  • Should HIPAA Security Rule documentation be maintained  by the individual responsible for HIPAA Security Rule  implementation?  • Should HIPAA Security Rule documentation be updated in  response to periodic evaluations, following security  incidents, and/or after acquisitions of new technology or new  procedures?  • Have dates of creation and validity periods been included in  all documentation?  • Has appropriate management reviewed and approved all  documentation?  2. Retain Documentation for at  Least Six Years  Implementation Specification  (Required)  • Retain documentation required by paragraph (b)(1) of this  section for six years from the date of its creation or the date  when it last was in effect, whichever is later.  • Have documentation retention requirements under HIPAA  been aligned with the organization’s other data retention  policies?  3. Ensure that Documentation is  Available to Those Responsible  for Implementation  Implementation Specification  (Required)  • Make documentation available to those persons  responsible for implementing the procedures to which the  documentation pertains.  • Is the location of the documentation known to all staff who  need to access it?  • Is availability of the documentation made known as part of  education, training, and awareness activities?141  4. Update Documentation as  Required  Implementation Specification  (Required)  • Review documentation periodically and update as needed  in response to environmental or operational changes that  affect the security of the ePHI.  • Is there a version control procedure that allows for the  verification of the timeliness of policies and procedures, if  reasonable and appropriate?  • Is there a process for soliciting input into updates of  policies and procedures from staff, if reasonable and  appropriate?  • Are policies and procedures updated in response to  environmental or operational changes that affect the  security of ePHI?  141 See Section 5.1.5, HIPAA Standard: Security Awareness and Training. In the [NIST CSF], for example, six informative 1437  references were included (as shown in Figure 1) although many other informative references 1438  could have been useful to stakeholders. While the concept of informative references was well 1439  received, the static nature of the Cybersecurity Framework and other NIST documents that 1440  include informative references meant that some of its informative references became outdated as 1441  the documents they referenced were updated. 1442  1443  1444  Within the context of the National Online Informative References [NIST OLIR] Program, an 1445  informative reference indicates the relationship(s) between the elements of two documents. The 1446  source document, called the Focal Document, is used as the basis for the document comparison. 1447  The second document is called the Reference Document. Note that a Focal Document or a 1448  Reference Document is not necessarily in a traditional document format (e.g., a formal 1449  publication in PDF format) but could be a product, service, or training. A Focal Document 1450  Element or a Reference Document Element is a discrete section, sentence, phrase, or other 1451  identifiable piece of content of a document. 1452  The OLIR Program is a NIST effort to facilitate subject matter experts (SMEs) in defining 1453  standardized relationships between elements of their cybersecurity, privacy, and workforce 1454  documents (Reference Documents) and elements of other cybersecurity, privacy, and workforce 1455  documents (Focal Documents), like the Cybersecurity Framework Version 1.1 and NIST [SP 1456  800-53], Rev. 5. By removing the informative references from within the NIST documents, the 1457  OLIR program scales to accommodate a greater number of informative references while 1458  providing a more agile model for updating the relationships between elements of the Reference 1459  and Focal Documents.  1460  Figure 1 - Informative References Included in Cybersecurity Framework  NIST SP 800-66r2 ipd  IMPLEMENTING THE HIPAA SECURITY RULE:  INITIAL PUBLIC DRAFT  A CYBERSECURITY RESOURCE GUIDE  105  The National OLIR Program provides an online catalog for displaying, sharing, and comparing 1461  informative references. The National OLIR Program offers several benefits, including: 1462  • Provides a single, easy-to-use repository where people can obtain information on many 1463  Reference Documents and analyze their relationships 1464  • Increases the transparency, alignment, and harmonization of definitions and concepts 1465  across Reference Documents 1466  • Standardizes how References are expressed – making them more consistent, clear, usable, 1467  repeatable, and organizable – and provides a way for automation technologies to ingest 1468  and utilize them 1469  • Provides the ability to authenticate the source of each Reference and allows users to 1470  identify whether the Reference was provided by a verified SME 1471  • Employs mathematical rigor (e.g., standard set theory principles, such as subset, superset, 1472  equal, intersect, and discrete logic) to express References rather than merely relying on 1473  prose, which can be ambiguous and subjective 1474  • Allows for the cybersecurity and privacy community to keep information current on 1475  relationship assertions between Reference Documents and Focal Documents 1476  Before the National OLIR Program, a person analyzing documents was often forced to conduct a 1477  manual comparison, typically by copying the contents of both documents into a spreadsheet for 1478  easier searching and sorting. To save time, an analyst might try to leverage existing document 1479  mappings from SMEs. This laborious and error-prone process would be repeated for all of the 1480  elements within the Focal Document and the Reference Document. Multiply this process by 1481  numerous analysts performing the task, and two problems quickly emerge: 1) the different 1482  opinions of analysts result in inconsistent associations, and 2) the analysts duplicate an enormous 1483  amount of effort. Streamlining this process is the main reason the OLIR Derived Relationship 1484  Mappings (DRM) capability was created. 1485  DRMs are the result of using the relationships between Reference Documents and a Focal 1486  Document to make inferences about relationships between the Reference Documents. For 1487  example, the OLIR catalog contains an informative reference that maps elements of the 1488  Cybersecurity Framework to elements in NIST SP 800-53, Rev. 5. Another informative 1489  reference maps elements of the Cybersecurity Framework to elements in two versions of the 1490  HITRUST CSF [HITRUST]. A DRM can be created that depicts the relationships between the 1491  two Reference Documents: NIST SP 800-53, Rev.5 and the HITRUST CSF. These DRMs can be 1492  dynamically generated on the OLIR website. 1493  With much of the relationship data already defined by the SME, a user can simply generate a full 1494  report between two Reference Documents and export it to a comma-separated values format. The 1495  user can sort the reference data by Functions, Categories, Subcategories, Control Families, 1496  Security/Privacy Controls, or Security Control Enhancements (depending on the Focal 1497  Document selected). The user can then better understand the similarities and differences between 1498  the elements and determine which relationships are relevant for their purposes.  1499  In the context of HIPAA compliance, Table 12 in Appendix E lists mappings between elements 1500  of the Security Rule (i.e., standards and implementation specifications); elements of SP 800-53, 1501  Rev. 5 (i.e., security and privacy controls); and elements of the Cybersecurity Framework (i.e., 1502  NIST SP 800-66r2 ipd  IMPLEMENTING THE HIPAA SECURITY RULE:  INITIAL PUBLIC DRAFT  A CYBERSECURITY RESOURCE GUIDE  106  Subcategory outcomes).
